botanical_details.genus: Chrysanthemum are erect woody-based perennials with aromatic, pinnately lobed leaves and flowerheads of diverse form, from late summer to late autumn
botanical_details.horticultural_group: Reflexed, Early flowering Outdoor Spray chrysanthemums are upright plants with medium-sized, fully double flowerheads, the florets curved outwards from the centre, flowering in late summer and autumn

how_to_grow.cultivation: Grow in a sheltered site in full sun in fertile well-drained soil, enriched with organic matter and general purpose fertiliser. Water freely in dry weather. Pinching out the growing tip when the plants are 15-20cm tall to encourage free flowering bushy plants. Staking is usually required. There is no need to deadhead. In mild areas leave in the ground protected by a thick mulch. Elsewhere lift the crowns and store in a greenhouse, raising fresh plants from these each year
how_to_grow.propagation: Propagate by softwood cuttings taken in spring from shoots from stored stools
how_to_grow.pruning: Cut back to near ground level in the autumn, before lifting and storing for the winter
how_to_grow.pests: May be susceptible to aphids and leaf miners. Leaf and bud eelworms can damage stock that has not been heat-treated; earwigs sometimes damage blooms and capsid bug and glasshouse red spider mite are occasional pests
how_to_grow.diseases: May be susceptible to chrysanthemum white rust which can be very damaging and hard to control. Powdery mildews in dry conditions; grey moulds and other fungal rots can be severe in wet conditions and a virus can cause stunting and leaf markings
